definitions.definition: a part of a tree that grows out from the main stem and on which leaves, flowers and fruit grow

examples.text: She climbed the tree and hid in the branches.
the bare branches of a tree in winter

definitions.definition: a local office or shop belonging to a large company or organization

examples.text: The bank has branches all over the country.
Our New York branch is dealing with the matter.
The store is opening more local branches.
He has been named assistant branch manager at a new branch of the bank.
the Post Office announced plans to close another branch.

definitions.definition: a part of a government or other large organization that deals with one particular aspect of its work

examples.text: Scotland Yard's anti-terrorist branch swung into action.
The idea was so popular, other branches of government copied it.
She was national branch secretary of the union.

definitions.definition: a division of an area of knowledge or a group of languages

examples.text: the branch of computer science known as ‘artificial intelligence’
Quantum analysis is a branch of statistics.
The aim is to bring together researchers from different branches of geography.

definitions.definition: a smaller or less important part of a river, road, railway, etc. that leads away from the main part

examples.text: a **branch line** *(= a small line off a main railway line, often in country areas)*

definitions.definition: a group of members of a family who all have the same ancestors

examples.text: My uncle's branch of the family emigrated to Canada.

definitions.definition: completely and in a way that affects every part of something

examples.text: The government set out to destroy the organization root and branch.

wordOrigin: Middle English: from Old French branche, from late Latin branca ‘paw’.
